etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in American Naturalist. From scientific Latin Polynoe, genus name + -id, after scientific Latin Polynoidae, family name

definitions: Any of various errant polychaete worms constituting the family Polynoidae, having a flattened body with a series of plates or elytra covering most of the dorsal surface; a scale worm.
Of or relating to the family Polynoidae.
